awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Broad Spectrum Antimicrobial Surface Coating (COVID-19)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project is to minimize the number of hospital-associated infections which contribute to almost 100,000 deaths each year in the US at an annual cost exceeding $30 B. Reducing the surface-borne transmission of pathogens can limit the spread of pathogenic diseases, thus minimizing transmission from contaminated surfaces in both public and healthcare settings is of utmost importance. Disinfectants can inactivate pathogens but require an active engagement that places undue burden on personnel and the environment; furthermore, the success rate varies, and the results do not persist. Most current antimicrobial materials are expensive, toxic to humans and the environment, and show minimal viral inactivation. Self-decontaminating surfaces provide a much-needed solution to these limitations, especially in areas with high-touch surfaces and large population flow. Customers, from hardware and elevator manufacturers to hospitals and airlines, will benefit from an effective, low-cost, environmentally sound solution to decontamination and customer safety for conditions such as the current COVID-19 pandemic.  This project has potential impact for the $8 B antimicrobial coatings market, while delivering improved clinical outcomes. 

This STTR Phase I project proposes to demonstrate the efficacy of a breakthrough, permanent ceramic coating technology against both viruses and bacteria.  A pure ceramic coating that exceeds the Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA’s) requirements will be synthesized and deposited on relevant substrates. The key to reaching this goal is gaining an understanding of the mechanism of microbial inactivation – believed to be the spontaneous generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) on the surface of the ceramic – and how to maximize them in a practical coating. Spectroscopic techniques will be used to rapidly assess the number and type of ROS generated and thus the efficacy of the materials. Optimization will occur through the addition/substitution of targeted alkali, alkaline earth, transition, and/or main-group metals to control the lattice of the material and lock-in specific valence states to optimize the ability of the ceramic to generate large numbers of the appropriate reactive oxygen species. Tests will be performed against both viral and bacterial challenges to correlate the results of the rapid screening assessment with antimicrobial effectiveness. Pure ceramic thin films will be deposited, and the antimicrobial efficacy of these films tested.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimate that ~1.7 million healthcare-acquired infections per year in the US contribute to nearly 100,000 deaths at an annual cost of over $30B. Roughly 5% of all hospital patients will become infected making healthcare acquired infections one of the leading causes of death (on par with diabetes and Alzheimer?s). Healthcare facilities are particularly dangerous as the mortality rate of infected patients is more than 30% higher than from the same infections acquired outside of a healthcare setting.

Unlike COVID-19, healthcare acquired infections are transmitted primarily by fomites (surfaces) ? and pathogens can remain viable on surfaces for over a year. It is well-known that reducing the fomite transmission of pathogens can limit the spread of viral and bacterial diseases. Disinfectants can inactivate pathogens on surfaces, but the results do not persist: once fully dry, disinfectants are no longer active. Disinfectants are toxic to people and the environment and there is no guarantee of success: up to 2/3 of all surfaces in hospitals remain contaminated after disinfection.

During the Phase I STTR effort the Nanoionix team developed and tested a family of over 20 engineered, robust self-decontaminating ceramic surface coatings that inactivate both bacteria and viruses. The team demonstrated these coatings on materials representative of medical devices, hospital equipment, and the general healthcare environment including metal, plastic, textile, and ceramic substrates. Pathogens tested include E. Coli and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), two leading causes of healthcare acquired infections and vaccinia, a surrogate for smallpox and monkeypox. Nanoionix? materials provide a permanent, robust, air-, water-, and thermally- stable antimicrobial coating, are resilient to repeated contact and cleaning with harsh solvents, chemicals, and abrasives (if needed), and by design, low-cost and non-toxic. No light, heat, or electrical stimulation is required for the coatings to be effective.

A scientific understanding of the mechanism of action of microbial inactivation was established ? the spontaneous generation of reactive oxygen species. This allowed the team to develop a rapid screening test to both predict the material?s antimicrobial performance based on surface chemistry and to create a rigorous process for materials? optimization. The coatings are active for at least months and meet the US Environmental Protection Agency requirements for persistent antimicrobial coatings: more than 99.9% pathogen inactivation in 2 hours. In some cases, greater than 99.9% viral inactivation was observed in less than 5 minutes. Competing materials are expensive, toxic to humans and the environment, and most show minimal viral inactivation ? and therefore are rarely used in critical healthcare settings such as operating rooms, intensive care units, and on medical equipment.

The use of Nanoionix? coatings can reduce the human and financial burden of healthcare acquired infections and minimize the impact of future pandemics. Additional market opportunities include food and beverage processing, packaging, and storage; air and water filtration, ducting, and piping; high-touch hardware (knobs/handles, sinks/faucets/toilets); textiles (personal protective equipment, sports uniforms); and transportation systems (automotive, aircraft, train, bus). The team is now engaged with a Fortune 200 company to scale-up, manufacture, and distribute its products.

 


Last Modified: 03/14/2023
Modified by: Dana Totir
